thread.title: Sydney weather: It’s hot today — but no record breaker (for now) | Daily Telegraph
thread.title_full: Sydney weather: It’s hot today — but no record breaker (for now) | Daily Telegraph

title: Sydney weather: It’s hot today — but no record breaker (for now) | Daily Telegraph
text:
Sydney weather: It’s hot today — but no record breaker (for now) The Daily Telegraph February 5, 2017 4:03pm 
IT CAME so close, but with today’s city maximum peaking at 34.9C, it looks like the 120-year-old record run of 35C-plus days is safe — for now. 
The long standing record of nine days above 35C during the one summer was set in 1896, and with Sydney already having racked up that number of scorchers this summer so far, it looked like Sunday might be the day it was at last surpassed 
But it was not to be, with the mercury settling at 34.9 just after 12.30pm, and with the sea breeze bring welcome relief to the city in the afternoon, it seemed unlikely temperatures would creep back up. media_camera Another boiling hot day in Sydney — and that means beach weather! Gordons Bay was packed with swimmers. Picture: Bob Barker. media_camera Gordons Bay was the perfect spot for a dip. Picture: Bob Barker. 
However, Bureau Of Meteorology duty meteorologist Zach Porter noted that there was still another 23 days left of summer, and plenty of time for the record to be broken. 
“It’s definitely possible, and the way the weather is behaving lately, I think there is a very decent chance,” he said. 
While Monday’s weather looks set to head above the 30C mark, there will be a brief respite on Tuesday and Wednesday before the temperature lifts again later in the week. 
Last night, it hovered around the 27C mark — but things got even stickier for Blacktown residents when a substation fire caused a blackout in the area. 
A fire in a substation on Herwood Hwy, just off Main St in Blacktown, saw power cut from 1800 Endeavour customers in the area about 12am, before being restored just after 3am. 
An Endeavour Energy spokesman said the cause of the fire was now being investigated. media_camera Large parts of Blacktown were plunged into darkness a fire broke out in an electrical substation. Picture: Gordon McComiskie media_camera Firefighters at the scene of the blaze. Picture: Gordon McComiskie 
He said the most pressure on the network came on weekdays when business was in full swing, with the biggest load the network had supplied occurring in February 2011, when Sydney endured more than a week of temperatures above 30C. 
In the Hunter Region, a lighting strike near Scone a around 5pm saw power cut to around 1200 Ausgrid customers, with services fully restored by midnight, while a few hours later in Newcastle, more lightning saw 800 customers cut off in the Warners Bay and Macquarie Hills areas, with power completely restored just after 10pm.
